results.adx_keywords: Football (College);Colleges and Universities;Florida State University;Winston, Jameis;Sex Crimes;Tallahassee (Fla);Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings;Domestic Violence;Police;Fisher, Jimbo;Crime and Criminals
results.byline: By MIKE McINTIRE and WALT BOGDANICH
results.title: At Florida State, Football Clouds Justice
results.abstract: Police and court records and interviews with witnesses show that the Tallahassee police on numerous occasions have soft-pedaled allegations of wrongdoing by Seminoles football players.

media.caption: Jimbo Fisher, the head coach of the Florida State University Seminoles, and the team’s star quarterback, Jameis Winston.

A sign showed support for the Florida State Seminoles football team in Tallahassee this month. Evidence of Seminole fever is everywhere in the city, where officials say each home game pumps up to $10 million into the local economy.
Passengers waiting for flights at the Tallahassee Regional Airport in front of a mural of the Florida State University football team.

Jesus (Bobo) Wilson was charged with grand-theft auto in the stealing of a motor scooter, but the charge was later reduced to a misdemeanor. The officer who initially stopped Mr. Wilson in the case did not arrest him, and the Tallahassee police are conducting an inquiry into their handling of the affair.
Mr. Wilson during a game last year against Boston College.
A report describing a police stop in which Mr. Wilson, a F.S.U. wide receiver, was not arrested after riding a stolen motor scooter.

A web page from a booster club called Old School, showing a photograph from a 2012 fund-raiser in which Dennis Jones, right, then the Tallahassee police chief, kicked off the event by firing a shotgun. At left is Paul Phipps, then an assistant athletic director for marketing at F.S.U.
A sign showed support for the Florida State Seminoles football team in Tallahassee this month.

results.title: Losses Leave Patriots on the Defensive
results.abstract: Tom Brady’s Patriots are 2-2, with a sputtering offense, and at 37 he has a quarterback rating that is 27th in the league.

media.caption: Tom Brady, who answered questions Wednesday about his 2-2 Patriots team, said, “We’ve got to find ways to do a better job.”

results.adx_keywords: Soccer;Solo, Hope;Domestic Violence;United States Soccer Federation;United States Women's National Soccer Team
results.title: In Hope Solo Case, Soccer Turns a Blind Eye Toward Domestic Violence
results.abstract: Hope Solo, the star goalie of the United States national women’s team, has been allowed to play and wore the captain’s armband despite accusations she punched her sister and nephew.
org_facet: UNITED STATES WOMEN'S NATIONAL SOCCER TEAM

media.caption: Hope Solo extended her shutout record to 73 in the United States national women’s soccer team’s 4-0 victory over Mexico in Rochester.
Hope Solo appeared in Kirkland Municipal Court on June 23 in connection with her arrest on domestic violence charges.

results.adx_keywords: Track and Field;Chand, Dutee;Testosterone;Women and Girls;International Assn of Athletics Federations
results.title: Fighting for the Body She Was Born With
results.abstract: Dutee Chand, India’s 100-meter champion in the 18-and-under category, was barred from competing against women because of naturally elevated testosterone levels.

media.caption: Dutee Chand can return to competition only if she lowers her testosterone level. “I’m not changing for anyone,” she said.
media.copyright: Graham Crouch for The New York Times

media.caption: Chand, left, after taking the bronze medal in the women's 200 meters at the Asian Athletics Championship last year. Her compatriot Asha Roy took the silver.
Payoshni Mitra, a researcher and activist on gender and sports, suggested that Chand appeal the ban that has kept her from competing.
media.copyright: Graham Crouch for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Football;Hazing;Sex Crimes;Sayreville (NJ);Sayreville War Memorial High School (Sayreville, NJ);Interscholastic Athletics
results.title: Cancellation of High School Football Season Leads Sayreville to Ask What Happens Next
results.abstract: On Friday afternoon, with the vaunted football team in Sayreville, N.J., shut down, residents were left divided and disturbed by sex-crime charges against seven players ages 15 to 17.
org_facet: SAYREVILLE WAR MEMORIAL HIGH SCHOOL (SAYREVILLE, NJ)

media.caption: The Sayreville Leprechauns, a New Jersey youth program, practicing on Friday, which was originally the day of Sayreville War Memorial High School's homecoming football game.
media.copyright: Matt Rainey for The New York Times

media.caption: Sayreville’s football season was canceled last week after accusations of hazing. On Friday, seven players faced charges of sexual crimes.
media.copyright: Matt Rainey for The New York Times

media.caption: Teenagers played basketball Friday.
media.copyright: Matt Rainey for The New York Times

media.caption: Sayreville's football team drew a passionate fan base.
media.copyright: Matt Rainey for The New York Times

media.caption: A sign on Main Street displayed the high school team's schedule.
John Shara, a Sayreville resident, said places like Angelo’s Pizza were often quiet on football Fridays.
media.copyright: Matt Rainey for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: News and News Media;Simmons, Bill;ESPN;Grantland;Beck, Glenn
results.byline: By JONATHAN MAHLER and RICHARD SANDOMIR
results.title: Bill Simmons’s Return Sets Intrigue in Motion at ESPN
results.abstract: Simmons, whose three-week suspension for calling Roger Goodell a liar ends Wednesday, could be something of a litmus test for the power of individual brands in a shifting media landscape.

media.caption: Bill Simmons during the N.B.A. All-Star Celebrity Game in February. He has transformed himself into much more than a sportswriter at ESPN, which hired him in 2002.
Glenn Beck began his own Internet channel after battling his bosses at Fox News.
Howard Stern left Viacom and is now heard on satellite radio.
Ezra Klein left a traditional news organization for a digital-media venture.
media.copyright: Daniel Rosenbaum for The New York Times

results.title: Fantasy Football: Tiered Player Ranking Charts, Running Back
results.abstract: Charts resulting from a statistical algorithm find natural tiers and clusters within fantasy football player ranking data.

media.caption: The chart shows the top 4 tiers of the defense/special teams rankings for Week 6. To view the charts for all positions, click here.

results.title: Fantasy Football: Tiered Player Ranking Charts, Wide Receiver
results.abstract: Charts resulting from a statistical algorithm find natural tiers and clusters within fantasy football player ranking data.

media.caption: The chart shows the top 4 tiers of the defense/special teams rankings for Week 6. To view the charts for all positions, click here.

results.title: Night’s Hero: Who Else?
results.abstract: With the eyes of a city and a sport upon him, Derek Jeter smacked the winning hit in the final at-bat of his final game at Yankee Stadium.

results.title: Fantasy Football: Tiered Player Ranking Charts
results.abstract: Charts resulting from a statistical algorithm find natural tiers and clusters within fantasy football player ranking data.

media.caption: The chart shows the top 4 tiers of the defense/special teams rankings for Week 6. To view the charts for all positions, click here.

results.title: Derek Jeter Takes In, and Provides, a Memorable Final View at Shortstop
results.abstract: After his game-ending hit on Thursday night and the ensuing celebration, Jeter walked alone to his shortstop position one last time and took it all in.

media.caption: Jeter took the field Thursday at the only position he has ever played.
media.copyright: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

media.caption: Jeter said it had felt strange during his final season to be present, in a way, at his own funeral.
media.copyright: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Football;National Football League;Kansas City Chiefs;Abdullah, Husain;Muslims and Islam
results.title: Flag on Praying Muslim Player Was an Error, the N.F.L. Says
results.abstract: The league said Chiefs safety Husain Abdullah should not have been penalized when he went to the “ground for religious reasons” after a touchdown.

media.caption: Husain Abdullah, a safety with the Chiefs who is Muslim, intercepted a pass by Tom Brady and returned it for a touchdown.
Husain Abdullah was given a 15-yard penalty at the end of this play for unsportsmanlike conduct.

results.adx_keywords: National Football League;Football;Domestic Violence;Women and Girls;News and News Media;Storm, Hannah;Nichols, Rachel;ESPN;CNN;Child Abuse and Neglect;Rice, Ray (1987- );Peterson, Adrian;Discrimination;Baltimore Ravens;Minnesota Vikings;Nolan, Katie
results.title: In Coverage of N.F.L. Scandals, Female Voices Puncture the Din
results.abstract: Female sports broadcasters driving the Ray Rice and Adrian Peterson stories see this as a potentially watershed moment for their profession, a turning point that could bring them more fully into the conversation.

media.caption: Hannah Storm during her N.F.L. essay on ESPN. “It was like jumping off a cliff,” she said. “I had no idea how it would be received.”

results.adx_keywords: Football;ESPN;Simmons, Bill;Goodell, Roger;Domestic Violence;Rice, Ray (1987- );National Football League;Television
results.title: Bill Simmons Suspended by ESPN for Tirade on Roger Goodell
results.abstract: Simmons, a writer and commentator, was suspended after he launched an obscenity-laced tirade against Goodell’s handling of the Ray Rice domestic violence case.

media.caption: ESPN suspended Bill Simmons for three weeks.
media.copyright: Amy Sussman/Getty Images The New Yorker

results.title: High-Fives, Not High Reps
results.abstract: Physical fitness for children has become big business as gyms and workout centers continue to wind back the ages of their youngest customers.

media.caption: At the CrossFit gym in Long Island City, Queens, the gym’s owner and coach, Michele Kelber, helped 3-year-old Georgia Costa work out.
media.copyright: Michael Appleton for The New York Times

media.caption: Adam Reznik, 4, made his way through a tunnel constructed out of red tumbling mats.
media.copyright: Michael Appleton for The New York Times

media.caption: Kelber played with Adam, left, Ella Reznik, 2, center, and Georgia, right. “It’s made for your kid to succeed in life,” Kelber said, “not to beat them down.”
media.copyright: Michael Appleton for The New York Times

results.byline: By MARY PILON, STEVE EDER and MATT KRUPNICK
results.title: In Death of Long Island High School Player, Perils of Football Reverberate
results.abstract: Tom Cutinella of Shoreham-Wading River High School was the third high school football player in the country to die in the past week.

media.caption: At a vigil for Tom Cutinella on Thursday at Shoreham-Wading River High School, players from Mount Sinai High School paid their respects.
media.copyright: Bryan Thomas for The New York Times

media.caption: Steven R. Cohen, the superintendent of Shoreham-Wading River schools, left, and the school's principal, Dan Holtzman, spoke at a news conference on Thursday.
A memorial for Cutinella, 16, who died Wednesday after a collision on the football field.
media.copyright: Bryan Thomas for The New York Times

media.caption: Shoreham-Wading River High School, where Tom Cutinella, 16, attended school and played football.

results.title: George Shuba, 89, Dies; Handshake Heralded Racial Tolerance in Baseball
results.abstract: Shuba, a Dodgers outfielder, is remembered for a welcoming gesture to Jackie Robinson on the day that Robinson, as a minor leaguer, broke baseball’s color barrier.

media.caption: George Shuba greeted Jackie Robinson, right, when Robinson broke baseball’s color barrier in a minor league game in 1946.
Shuba in 1948.

results.adx_keywords: College Athletics;Football (College);Colleges and Universities;Big Ten Conference;Ohio State University
results.title: As Big Ten Declines, Homegrown Talent Flees
results.abstract: The Big Ten is no longer the center of the football universe, as shifting demographics mean member states produce fewer top players and the area’s top recruits are drawn to powerhouses like the Southeastern Conference.

media.caption: Jerome Baker, talking with his teammates at Benedictine High School in Ohio, is a four-star linebacker and is appraised from 36th to 72nd nationally. He committed to play for the University of Florida.
media.copyright: Dustin Franz for The New York Times

media.caption: Utah's Kaelin Clay, second from left, celebrating a touchdown with Troy McCormick (21), Sharrieff Shah Jr. (59) and Davion Orphey in a Sept. 20 game against Michigan. The Utes won, 26-10.
The Southeastern Conference, where the University of Florida plays, won seven consecutive B.C.S. championships.
Archie Griffin, with his 1975 Heisman Trophy, was born in Columbus, Ohio. Griffin won the award in 1974 and 1975.
A week after the Big Ten had one of its worst showings in recent history, Commissioner Jim Delany went to New Jersey to spread Big Ten pride and preside over Rutgers’s first conference game.
media.copyright: Ben Solomon for The New York Times

media.caption: Ohio State Coach Urban Meyer recruited Jerome Baker for the university's football program but was unsuccessful.
Mekka Don performs at a party to introduce the Big Ten Network. The Big Ten has a billion-dollar deal with ABC/ESPN as well as the network,  which was the first of its kind when it debuted in 2007.
media.copyright: Ben Gabbe/Getty Images for Wink Public Relations

results.title: Of All His Numbers, the One on Jeter’s Back Matters Most
results.abstract: Take a long look at the pinstriped No. 2 Yankees jersey, which was worn on Thursday for the last time, an event that brought to mind prominent numerals cherished in other sports and eras.

media.caption: Derek Jeter's No. 2 will be retired after this season. Thursday's game was his last in Yankee pinstripes.
media.copyright: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times

media.caption: Orioles shortstop J.J. Hardy is proud to wear No. 2 because "It's a Jeter thing."
The 1995 Yankees yearbook shows Jeter with No. 70. On May 29 of that year, he was given No. 2, which will be retired.

results.title: Errors in Inquiry on Rape Allegations Against FSU’s Jameis Winston
results.abstract: An accusation against Jameis Winston, a marquee quarterback for Florida State, did not prompt an in-depth inquiry by either the university or the police. By the time prosecutors got the case it was nearly a year old.
